ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:0.2_0: The monks’ rules and their analysis
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:0.3_0: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.2_0: At that time a certain brahmin had invited the monks for a meal.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.3_0: When the monks had finished and refused an invitation to eat more, they went to their respective families, where some ate and some took away almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.4_0: Soon afterwards that brahmin said to his neighbors,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.5_0: “The monks have been satisfied by me.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.6_0: Come, and I’ll satisfy you, too.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.8_0: Those monks who were invited by you came to our houses. Some of them ate there and some took away almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.9_0: He complained and criticized the nuns,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.10_0: “How can the venerables eat in our house and afterwards eat elsewhere?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.11_0: Am I not able to give them as much as they need?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.12_0: The monks heard the criticism of that brahmin.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.13_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized her,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.14_0: “How can those monks finish their meal and refuse an invitation to eat more, and then eat elsewhere?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.15_0: “Is it true, monks, that monks did this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.18_0: “... How can those foolish men finish their meal and refuse an invitation to eat more, and then eat elsewhere?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.19_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.20_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.21.1_0: ‘If a monk has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, and then eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.22_0: The Buddha has laid down a training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.1_0: Soon afterwards the monks were bringing back fine almsfood for the sick monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.2_0: But because they were not able to eat as much as they had intended,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.3_0: the monks threw the leftovers away.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.4_0: The Buddha heard the loud sound of crows cawing,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.5_0: the Buddha asked Venerable Ānanda what it was,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.6_0: “Ānanda, why is there this loud sound of crows cawing?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.7_0: Ānanda told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.8_0: “But Ānanda, don’t the monks eat the leftovers from those who are sick?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.10_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.11_0: “Monks, I allow you to eat the leftovers both from those who are sick and from those who are not sick.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.12_0: And, monks, this is how you make food leftover:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.13_0: ‘I’ve had enough of all of this.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.14_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.15.1_0: ‘If a monk has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, and then eats staple or non-staple food that is not left over, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.2_0: and you have the same kind of perception ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.4_0: ... The monks who have been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.6_0: has eaten any of the five staple foods, even just what fits on the tip of a blade of grass.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.7_0: Refuses an invitation to eat more:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.8_0: eating is seen, staple food is seen, it is offered by one standing within arm’s reach, a refusal is seen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.10_0: it is done with food that has not been marked;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.11_0: it has not been put out;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.12_0: if it is done with food that hasn’t been done;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.13_0: it is done with food that hasn’t been put out;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.14_0: it is done by those who are ready
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.15_0: it is done by one who has finished his meal, who has refused an invitation to eat more, and who has refused an invitation to eat more,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.17_0: it is not leftover from one who is sick—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.20_0: the making it leftover is done with food that is allowable;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.21_0: it is done with food that has been received;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.22_0: it is done with food that is held in hand;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.23_0: it is done by one who is within arm’s reach;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.24_0: it is done by one who has finished his meal;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.25_0: it is done by one who has finished his meal, who has refused an invitation to eat more, and who has not risen from his seat;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.27_0: it is leftover from one who is sick—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.30_0: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics, the rest is called “non-staple food”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.32_0: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.33_0: If she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.1_0: If it is not leftover, and he does not perceive it as leftover, and he eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.2_0: If it is not leftover, but he is unsure of it, and he eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.3_0: If it is not leftover, but he perceives it as such, and he eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.4_0: If she receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.5_0: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.6_0: If it is leftover, but he does not perceive it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.7_0: If it is leftover, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.8_0: If it is leftover, and he perceives it as such, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.2_0: if he eats it after having it made leftover;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.3_0: if he receives it with the intention of having it made leftover and then eats it;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.4_0: if he is taking food for the benefit of someone else;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.5_0: if he eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.6_0: if, when there is a reason, she makes use of post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.9_0: The fifth rule, the training rule on invitation, is finished.
